key_points: Royal biographer Andrew Morton discusses why Prince Harry and Meghan Markle might have refused a royal title for their son, Archie.
Morton suggests Harry and Meghan feared the title 'Earl of Dumbarton' might lead to bullying due to the word 'dumb' in it.
The concern was not about general bullying for being royal but specific mockery because of the title's name.
There's contention around whether Harry and Meghan had the choice in Archie's titled status, with Meghan offering a different version during an Oprah Winfrey interview.
Meghan spoke about the Royal Family's reluctance to make Archie a prince, which differed from the protocol.
Meghan's revelations highlight concerns about Archie's safety and the importance of his royal status in that context.
The issue of denying Archie the prince title and the decision against the 'Earl of Dumbarton' title may both be true, highlighting distinct concerns.
Morton views the refusal of the title as indicative of the Sussexes' sensitivity to their public image.
The decision could also reflect a parental desire to protect Archie from potential bullying.
Harry and Meghan's own experiences with public scrutiny and bullying could have influenced their protective stance.
